One of the bank members is Lorena, whose last survey showed her to be at level three of poverty, which is to say with good income.  However, she knows that the work and effort she is putting in have to be ongoing and permanent.  She tells us that among the kinds of work she does are housekeeping and buying and selling cheese and essential items in her free time.  She is a very hardworking and enterprising woman who wants to get ahead, which is why she is putting in so much effort.  

Lorena is asking for this loan to buy essential items, such as oil, soap, sugar, and flour, which will help her solidify her business plan and improve her income.

loans.use: to buy essential items, such as oil, soap, sugar, and flour

loans.name: Filomina

texts.en:
Filomina is 61 years old, married, and has three children. She lives in Gata Daiot, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She has been operating her small sari-sari (variety store) for more than two years, to make a living.

In 2011 Filomina joined Gata Daku MPC. She successfully repaid her previous loan, which she used to buy more stock for sale at her store. Recently, she needed some additional capital for her business, for it is the main source of income for her family now. She borrowed a loan of 8,000 PHP, which she will use to buy more dried fish, vegetables and spices to sell. She hope to improves her business outcome and generate more income. She wants to have a better living standard in the future, with her family.

loans.use: to buy more dried fish, vegetables and spices to sell

loans.name: Leopolda

texts.en: Leopolda is married with one child and lives in Clarin, Misamis Occidental with her family. Her husband provides transportation services in their motorcycle transport business while Loepolda runs a general store in the town market to make a living. She has been in her business for many years to support the needs of the entire family. She joined Gata Daku MPC and it helps her to improve her ability to engage in business. She has successfully repaid her previous loans that she used for additional capital for her business. Recently, she borrowed of 8,000.00 PHP to purchase tires and spare parts for her motorcycle. She wants to improve the general living condition of her family in the future.

loans.use: to purchase tires and spare parts for her motorcycle.

loans.name: Maa Parbati Mm Group

texts.en: Sukanti is 38 years old and married. She lives in a village in the Khurda district with her husband and her two children. Her husband earns a living by farming rice and vegetables. She is engaged in the activity of selling rice in her village, having been in this business for three years, and she manages to earn about 3,000 INR per month. This is a group loan for Sukanti's group of eight women named Maa Parbati MM. She is leading her group to apply for a loan. Sukanti wants to use her loan portion to buy more rice in bulk and sell it in the market. She hopes to increase her rice business and earn more income to better her living conditions. The members of the group Maa Parbati MM are very ambitious and are engaged in different kinds of activities like agriculture, retail stores, catering, dairy farming, vegetable selling etc.

loans.use: to purchase rice in bulk for her shop.

loans.name: Gundegmaa

texts.en:
Mrs. Gundegmaa. 42 years old, lives with her husband and three children in Erdenet, the third largest city of Mongolia. Her husband has been working as a teacher at an automobile driving school since 2009. Gundegmaa has been working as a weaver at a carpet factory for almost ten years. Her elder son is graduating from his university next year, and her daughter is beginning her university studies this September. Her youngest son goes to high school.

Because two children will be studying at university this year, affording tuition will be a problem for the family. So Gundegmaa is requesting a loan of 4,400,000 MNT to pay the tuition. She thinks university education will help her children in the future and open infinite opportunities to them.

loans.use: to pay tuition for her son in his last year, and her daughter in her first year, at university

loans.name: Enkhtuvshin

texts.en: Enkhtuvshin, 38 years old, lives with his wife and two daughters in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. The family resides in a house on a plot of land. He worked at an automobile dismantling factory in Japan between 1999 and 2004 and due to a factory accident he broke his left leg, quit his job and came back to Mongolia. He receives a monthly pension from Japan fund for his disability. His elder daughter is enrolling in university this September. His wife stays at home looking after their younger daughter. He is requesting a loan of 1,000,000 MNT to pay for his daughter's tuition fee. He thinks getting a university education will help his daughter to reach her dream.

loans.use: to pay for his daughter's tuition fee

loans.name: Bayarsaikhan

texts.en: Mr. Bayarsaikhan, 46 years old, lives with his son in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. His wife works in Turkey as a home teacher and housekeeper and she transfers money to her family. He has been rendering transportation service to local people since 2009. His eldest son lives on his own separately from his parents. Last year, with his savings and his wife's sent money, he purchased a two-room old apartment. As his wife is coming to Mongolia this September, he wants to welcome her with a renovated comfortable home. So he is requesting a loan of 2,800,000 MNT to purchase vacuum insulated windows, hardwood flooring, wallpaper, fiberglass and foam. After renovation, his family will live in a comfortable and warm place where heat won't be lost easily through walls and windows. The borrower is a very hardworking individual who deeply cares for his family.

loans.use: to purchase vacuum insulated windows, hardwood floors and fiberglass

loans.name: Lkhagvasuren

texts.en: Lkhagvasuren is 36 years old and lives with his wife and daughter in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. The family resides in a traditional Mongolian ger (portable felt dwelling) on a plot of land. He has been working as a driver for a building company for almost four years and during his day off, he provides taxi service to local people. His wife is a human resource manager at cashmere fashion company, currently working for a trial period. His daughter goes to kindergarten. He is requesting a loan of 1000000 MNT to purchase spare parts to repair his automobile which is an essential part of income generation for his family. The borrower is a very hard-working individual who strives for a better future.

loans.use: to buy spare parts to repair his automobile

loans.name: Benkadi 6 Group

texts.fr:
Les 10 membres du groupe  Benkadi 6 sont des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 45 ans, 5 enfants et vivant toutes dans des  familles traditionnelles à DJIGONSSO, un des villages de BOUGOURA, 4ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. 
Elles sont à leur 4eme prêt avec l’institution, les prêts passés ont été bien remboursés.
La spéculation cultivée est  l’arachide  avec  SITAN ZE  2 eme debout  de la gauche vers la droite sur la photo.
Avec son prêt, elle compte acheter des intrants, des semences, des petits matériels agricoles et payer les frais de labour pour entretenir  0,5 hectare. 
La production sera vendue au niveau du village et au marché après la récolte, à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice de 72500FCFA en fin de campagne.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer son prêt et aussi d’aider son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes.
texts.en: The ten members of the Benkadi 6 group are married women who are on average 45 years old, have five children, and live in traditional families in DJIGONSSO, one of the villages in BOUGOURA, the fourth administrative region of Mali. They are working with microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso to be able to see through their agricultural businesses in the rainy seasons. They are on their fourth loan with the institution, and all of their loans have been properly repaid. SITAN ZE, the second one standing from the left in the photo, grows peanuts. With her loan, she plans to buy ingredients, seeds, and small agricultural tools and to pay for the labor to maintain 0.5 hectares. The crops will be sold at the village and market after the harvest to a clientele made up of men and women. She plans to make a profit of 72,500 FCFA at the end. This profit will allow her to repay her loan and also to help her husband with daily expenses.

loans.use: to pay for labor, ingredients, small agricultural tools, and seeds

loans.name: Delia

texts.en:
Delia is very thankful for the financial assistance given to her. She used the loan as additional capital for her business. She has a Direct Selling and a buy and sell business. Her income from her businesses is helping with their everyday expenditures.

She would like to apply for another 15,000 PHP loan to buy more merchandise to increase her product inventory. The more items she has on display and available on hand, the better. More items to sell will result in better profits. Her profits from her business will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Delia hopes to have a product center and dreams of helping her family and loved ones financially. She meets with her co-fellowship members* every week, to share stories of her work and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to purchase additional merchandise like  undergarments, and cosmetics to sell

loans.name: Anatolio

texts.en:
This is Anatolio. He previously accessed a 10,000 PHP loan to purchase a variety of fish needed in his business. His earnings were a big help for the education of his children and in meeting their personal, household and business expenses.

He would like to apply for another 25,000 PHP loan to pay for a variety of fish needed in his business. More items to sell will result in better profit. His profits from his business will definitely help him to sustain his family's daily needs and cover the educational expenses of his children. He looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in his heart.

Anatolio dreams that his business will continue to flourish and hopes to have a good future. He meets up with his co-fellowship members to share stories of his work every week and also draws strength and inspiration from the Word of God he studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for a variety of fish needed in his business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for more pizza as needed in her business.

loans.name: Wend Goudoum Group

texts.fr:
Mme ZARATA représente le groupe WEND GOUDOUM. Elle se porte bien. Mariée, elle est mère de 04enfants. Le plus âgé a 14ans et le moins âgé a 06ans. 04 vont à l’école.
Mme fait la restauration (vente d’haricot) depuis 09ans. Elle s’approvisionne au marché de Kilwin. Ses clients sont les gens de son quartier.
Elle veut s’acheter 04sachets d’attiéké (couscous de manioc), 01bidon d’huile et  01sac d’haricot.
Avec ses bénéfices, elle veut  renforcer son activité. Mme ambitionne  agrandir son commerce et  mieux scolariser ses enfants dans de meilleurs écoles.
texts.en: Mrs. ZARATA represents the WEND GOUDOUM group. She feels well. She is a married mother of four. The oldest is 14 years old, and the youngest is 6 years old. All four attend school. Mrs. ZARATA has been in the restaurant business (she sells beans) for nine years. She stocks up at the market in Kilwin. Her customers are people in her neighborhood. She wants to buy four sacks of attiéké (manioc couscous), a container of oil, and a sack of beans. With her profits, she wants to build up her business. Mrs. ZARATA has the ambition to grow her business and to give her children the best education by sending them to the best schools.

loans.use: to buy four sacks of attiéké (manioc couscous), a container of oil, and a sack of beans

loans.name: Benkadi 7 Group

texts.fr:
Les 6 membres du groupe  Benkadi 7 sont des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 45 ans, 6 enfants et vivant toutes dans des  familles traditionnelles à DJIGONSSO commune de BOUGOURA cercle  de BLA, 4ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. 
Elles sont à leur 4eme prêt avec l’institution, les prêts passés ont été bien remboursés.
La spéculation cultivée est  l’arachide  avec  FANTA, 2 eme  femme debout de la gauche vers la droite sur la photo.
Avec son prêt, elle compte acheter des intrants, des semences, des petits matériels agricoles et payer les frais de labour pour entretenir  1,5 hectare. 
La production sera vendue au niveau du village et à YANGASSO après la récolte, à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice de 130.000FCFA en fin de campagne.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer son prêt et aussi d’aider son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes.
texts.en:
The six members of the group Benkadi 7 are married women who average 45 years of age and 6 children each, and who all live in traditional families in DJIGONSSO, in the commune of BOUGOURA, circle of BLA (4th administrative region of Mali). 

They joined the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso to sustain their farming activities during the rainy season. This is their 4th collaboration with the MFI, and all past loans were correctly repaid.  

Mrs. Fanta grows groundnuts. She is the group member standing second from the left in the photo. She will use her loan to buy inputs, seeds and small farming equipment, and to pay for the plowing needed to maintain 1.5 hectares of farmland. 

After the harvest, the crops will be sold in the village and in YANGASSO to a clientele consisting of both men and women. She expects to earn a profit of 130,000 FCFA by the end of the season, which she will use to repay her loan and to help her husband with the day-to-day expenses.

loans.use: to buy inputs, seeds and small farming equipment, and to cover the cost of plowing.

loans.name: Badegna Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre femmes du groupe Badegna sont mariées majoritairement dans des ménages monogamiques. Elles ont en moyenne 47 ans et 6 enfants. Elles habitent toutes dans le quartier de Sabalibougou dans le district de Bamako; Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage et de leurs activités génératrices de revenu au marché de Sabalibougou. Les membres du groupe font le petit commerce de légumes (oignon, patate,…), de vêtements de toutes sortes : pagnes wax, brodés, bazins et d’habits de la friperie. Dans le but d’augmenter leurs fonds de commerce, les membres du groupe ont décidé de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 2ème cycle de prêt solidaire.
Madame Maï (femme assise à l’extrême droite sur la photo) a une grande réputation dans la vente des pagnes wax, brodés, bazins. Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter 35 pièces de pagnes wax au grand marché en gros. La revente se fait  au comptant et à crédit à Sabalibougou et en ambulant à une clientèle composée majoritairement de femmes. Madame Mai espère réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 75. 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé, pour être réinvesti dans l’activité et assurer les soins de santé des enfants du foyer.
texts.en:
The four women of the group Badegna are for the most part married in monogamous households, and they average 47 years of age and six children each, all living in the Sabalibougou area of the Bamako district. They know one another through ties of community and through their revenue-generating businesses at the Sabalibougou market. The group members have small-scale businesses selling vegetables (onions, sweet potatoes, …), clothing of all sorts: Wax or embroidered 'pagnes' (the colorful cloth of western Africa), damask fabrics, and secondhand clothing. 

With the goal of increase their business capital, the group members decided to collaborate with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso and are now on their second solidarity loan cycle. 

Ms. Maï (sitting at the far right in the photo) has a great reputation selling Wax, embroidered, and damask fabrics. She intends to use her loan to purchase wholesale 35 lengths of Wax 'pagne' cloth at the big market. Accepting cash or credit, she resells them to a customer base composed mostly of women in Sabalibougou and by going door to door.  

With this loan, Ms. Maï hopes to make an average monthly profit of 75,000 francs CFA that will be used for reinvesting in her business and ensuring her children's healthcare at home.

loans.use: to purchase 'pagne' cloth

loans.name: Wilson

texts.en:
Wilson is from Gango, Ozamiz City. He is 39 years old, married, and has two children. To make a living, Wilson operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling cellphone accessories in the local community. Wilson has been engaged in his business for years, and it is his family's main source of income. His wife works as an office clerk in a private company.

He joined Gata Daku MPC in 2010, and he successfully repaid the previous loan, which he used to expand his business. Recently, he borrowed a loan of 15,000 PHP, which he will use to cover the costs of house repair. He plan to acquire a motorcycle to be used for the business. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business as a result of the loan, to improve the general living conditions of his family.

loans.use: to cover the costs of house repair

loans.name: Henry

texts.en: Henry is married with an only child and lives in Mialen, Clarin, Misamis Occidental with his family. He is 46 years old and operating a motor transportation service in his community. He has been doing this for many years as his main source of income. He joined Gata Daku MPC this year and borrowed a loan of 10,000 PHP to use for motor maintenance costs. He plans to save a portion of his generated income to acquire another unit of motor for his business expansion. He wants to improve the general living conditions of his family in the future.

loans.use: to pay for motor maintenance costs.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To pay for materials needed in repairing jewelry.

loans.name: Florife

texts.en:
Florife is thankful for the financial assistance given to her. She used the loan as additional capital for her business. She has a variety store, which she has been running for many years now. She also sells peanut butter for additional income. Sometimes she has a hard time collecting payments from her customers, but by the grace of God, she is able to continue her business and it is growing.

She would like to apply for another 50,000 PHP loan to buy more merchandise to increase her product inventory. The more items displayed at the store, the better. More items to sell will result in a better profit. Her profits from her business will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Florife hopes to have more customers and dreams of having other branches. She meets with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week, allowing her to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God that she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, to build social capital, and to repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for groceries, toiletries, and beverages to sell

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
This is Virginia, 57, a resident of Dasmariñas, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Salermo, and a mother to her eight children. She and her husband manage their own household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses.

Virginia is a mineral water distributor. What she basically does is buy mineral water in bulk from wholesalers and sell the water per container (5 gallons per container) for a profit. Her regular customers of her mineral water are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of PHP 500 in sales every day.

To help her continue operation of her business, she is requesting a PHP 8,000 loan. She will use the loan to buy more gallons of mineral water to expand her product inventory.

Virginia dreams to be successful in her business and hopes to have a good life. She meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and draws strength and inspiration from the Word of God he studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for more gallons of mineral water to expand her product inventory.

loans.name: Belinda

texts.en:
This is Belinda. She previously accessed an 8,000 PHP loan that she used to purchase more quantities and varieties of grocery items and products needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help for her children’s education, in their personal, household and business expenditures.

She would like to apply for another 10,000 PHP loan to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add to her inventory. The more items displayed at the store, the better. More items to sell will result in a better profit. Her profits from her business will definitely help sustain her family’s daily needs and her children’s educational expense. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Belinda dreams that her business will continue to flourish. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week, where she also draws strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God she studies.

All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items, toiletries, and beverages to expand her inventory.

loans.name: Samuel C's Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are teachers of a primary school located in Magburaka, a town in northern Sierra Leone. This group of teachers has come to SMT, a partner of Kiva.org, to apply for a loan of SLL 9,000,000 in order to meet their most immediate and most pressing financial needs. And at the end of each month, they can easily repay the loan using their salaries. It is their school’s bursar who is directly responsible for doing the deductions and making the repayments on their behalf.
 
Samuel is the featured leader of this group. Samuel is 41 year old. He is married and has four children who are attending primary and secondary schools. Samuel is a school teacher and has been in the teaching profession for 20 years now. Samuel has requested this loan in order to buy house building materials like cements, iron corrugated sheets, etc. to add to his business.

loans.use: to buy house building materials like cement, iron corrugated sheets, etc. to add to his business

loans.name: Dembagnouman Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Dembagnouman est constitué de quatre femmes mariées majoritairement dans des ménages monogamiques. Elles ont en moyenne 42 ans et 4 enfants. Elles habitent toutes dans le quartier de Sabalibougou dans le district de Bamako et se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage et de leurs activités génératrices de revenu au marché de Sabalibougou. Les membres du groupe font le petit commerce de légumes (choux pommés, tomates, poivron, oignon,…), des balais, des pagnes wax, brodés et bazins. Dans le but d’augmenter leurs fonds de commerce, les membres du groupe ont décidé de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 2ème cycle de prêt solidaire.
Madame Oumou (femme assise à l’extrême gauche sur la photo) est une grande vendeuse de toutes sortes de légumes. Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter 1sac de choux pommés, 5 baignoires de poivron et 200kg d’oignon à Bamako en gros. La revente se fait  au comptant et à crédit à Sabalibougou et à domicile à une clientèle composée majoritairement de femmes. Madame Oumou espère réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 80 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé, pour être réinvesti dans l’activité et assurer l’entretien des enfants du foyer.
texts.en:
The Dembagnouman comprises four married women for the most part in monogamous households. The women average 42 years of age and four children each, all living in the Sabalibougou area of the Bamako district. They know one another through ties of community and through their revenue-generating businesses at the Sabalibougou market. The group members have small-scale businesses selling vegetables (savoy cabbage, tomatoes, bell peppers, onions, …), brooms, 'pagnes' (the colorful cloth of western Africa), embroidered cloth, and damask fabrics. 

With the goal of increasing their business capital, the group members decided to collaborate with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso and are now on their second solidarity loan cycle. 

Ms. Oumou (sitting at the far left in the photo) has a great reputation selling all sorts of vegetables. She intends to use her loan to purchase wholesale 5 basins of bell peppers and 200 kg of onions in Bamako. Accepting cash or credit, she resells them to a customer base composed mostly of women in Sabalibougou and at home.  

With this loan, Ms. Oumou hopes to make an average monthly profit of 80,000 francs CFA that will be used for reinvesting in her business and caring for her children at home.

loans.use: to purchase vegetables

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
This is Gloria. She previously accessed a 10,000 PHP loan that she used to purchase more quantities and varieties of grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help in her personal, household and business expenditures.
 
She would like to apply for another 20,000 PHP loan to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add to her current inventory. The more items displayed at the store the better. More items to sell will result in a better profit. Her profits from her business will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Gloria hopes to have a general merchandise store someday and dreams of helping her grandchildren with their education. She meets with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week and to draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay micro finance loans.

loans.use: To purchase grocery items, toiletries and beverages to sell

loans.name: Moussa

texts.fr:
Âgé de 64 ans, Moussa est marié à  4 femmes et est père de 8 enfants. Il vit à Koutiala avec sa famille.  
Moussa est propriétaire et gérant d’un dépôt de vente de produits thérapeutiques à base de plantes, depuis plusieurs ans.  
Dans le souci de satisfaire les besoins de sa clientèle de plus en plus nombreuse, il décide de faire recours à l’institution de micro finance Soro Yiriwaso, avec qui il est à son 2ème prêt,  qui sera utilisé pour l’achat des plantes pour la fabrication des produits thérapeutiques. Il effectue sa vente en détail au comptant, à une clientèle mixte.
Mr envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 100.000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour rembourser le prêt, subvenir aux dépenses de sa famille et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en: At 64 years old, Moussa is married to four wives and is the father to eight children. He lives in Koutiala with his family. Moussa has been the owner and manager of a store that sells therapeutic products made from plants for several years. In the need to satisfy the needs of his growing clientele, he decided to seek the help of microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso, with whom he is on his second loan, which will be used to buy plants with which to make therapeutic products. He sells at retail for cash to a mixed clientele. Mr. Moussa forsees making a monthly profit of 100,000 FCFA, which will be used to repay his loan and pay for the needs of his family, and the rest will be invested in his business.

loans.use: to buy plants

loans.name: Eneria

texts.en:
Eneria is married with four children and lives in Clarin, Misamis Occidental with her family. Her husband is a rice farmer and the main source of income while Eneria runs a general store to make a living.

She joined GDMPC in 2007 and successfully repaid her previous loan that she used to purchase additional products to sell. Recently, she borrowed a loan of 50,000.00 PHP to buy more goods like slippers, kitchenware, grocery items and rice to sell. She hopes to have a better future and improve the general living situation of her family.

loans.use: to buy more goods like slippers, kitchenware, grocery items and rice to sell

loans.name: Sabougnouman Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Sabougnouman est constitué de six  femmes toutes mariées dans des ménages monogamiques. Elles ont en moyenne 50 ans et 7 enfants. Elles habitent toutes dans le quartier de Sabalibougou dans le district de Bamako; Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage et de leurs activités génératrices de revenu au marché de Sabalibougou. Les membres du groupe font le petit commerce de condiments (oignon, boîtes de tomate concentrée,…), de vêtements de toutes sortes : pagnes wax, brodés, bazins et d’habits de la fripouille. Dans le but d’augmenter leurs fonds de commerce, les membres du groupe ont décidé de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 2ème cycle de prêt solidaire.
Madame Ami (femme assise en 2ème position de la droite vers la gauche sur la photo) a une grande réputation dans la vente des habits de la fripouille de meilleures qualités; Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter 2 ballons d’habits de la friperie à Bamako en gros. La revente se fait  au comptant et à crédit  à Sabalibougou et en ambulant à une clientèle composée majoritairement de femmes. Madame Ami espère réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 50 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé, pour être réinvesti dans l’activité et assurer les soins de santé des enfants du foyer.
texts.en:
The group Sabougnouman comprises six married women in monogamous households. The women average 50 years of age and seven children each, all living in the Sabalibougou area of the Bamako district. They know one another through ties of community and through their revenue-generating businesses at the Sabalibougou market. The group members have small-scale businesses selling condiments (onions, canned tomato paste, …), secondhand clothing, and cloth of all sorts: wax, embroidered, damask.

With the goal of increasing their business capital, the group members decided to collaborate with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso and are now on their second solidarity loan cycle. 

Ms. Ami (sitting second from the right in the photo) has a great reputation for selling the best quality of used clothing. She intends to use her loan to purchase wholesale 2 bales of used clothing in Bamako. Accepting cash or credit, she resells the goods to a customer base composed mostly of women in Sabalibougou and by going door to door.  

With this loan, Ms. Ami hopes to make an average monthly profit of 50,000 francs CFA that will be used for reinvesting in her business and ensuring healthcare for the children at home.

loans.use: to purchase secondhand clothing to sell

loans.name: Binapani Group

texts.en:
Muniguda is a small town in the Rayagada district of Odisha, India where Gouri, about 30 years old, resides with her husband and two daughters who are about 9 & 12 years old. The lady standing at the extreme left with her hand raised in the photograph is Gouri. In the year 2010, she formed a JLG with four other members of her village to request a loan from Mahashakti Foundation.

Presently, Gouri has two cows and gets about eight liters of milk. She has more than five years experience in this business. Apart from that, she is also purchasing leaves and selling them after turning them into leaf plates. She earns about Rs.7,500/- (INR) per month from her total business. According to Gouri, this amount is not at all sufficient for her to manage the household expenditure as well as her business expenses. So she wants to expand her business to earn some extra income.

She has already received three loans from Mahashakti. This is her fourth loan. With the present loan, she wants to purchase a cow and leaves. Gouri has a dream that one day she will have a big dairy farm.

The other four members of the group, Shakuntala, Dhira, Kuntala and Purnami, are doing the same type of business: purchasing leaves and stitching them to make plates to sell at a higher rate.

loans.use: to purchase a cow and leaves to make  plates

loans.name: Akossiwa

texts.fr: Jeune femme de 30ans, Akossiwa pour subvenir à ses besoins revend de la salade de façon ambulante. Elle manque de fonds pour répondre aux besoins des clients, c'est pour cela, elle sollicite de WAGES un second crédit pour acheter de la nourriture. Elle espère réinvestir dans l'activité et a démarré en 2008.
texts.en: A young woman, Akossiwa is 30 years old, and to support herself, she hawks salads. She lacks the funds to respond to customer needs. For this reason, she is requesting a second loan from WAGES to purchase food. She hopes to reinvest in the business she started in 2008.

loans.use: to purchase salad, mayonnaise, and more.

loans.name: Ganga Group

texts.en:
Laxmi, about 29 years old, resides with her only son who is seven years old and her husband in Muniguda, in the Rayagada district in Odisha, India. The lady standing in the middle with her hand raised in the photograph is Laxmi. In the year 2010, she formed a JLG with four other members of her village to request a loan from Mahashakti Foundation.

Presently, Laxmi is purchasing leaves and making leaf plates. She has also been collecting leaf plates from other group members to wholesale for the last six years. She earns about Rs 7,000/- (INR) per month from her business. According to Laxmi, this amount is not at all sufficient to manage the household expenditure. So she wants to expand her business and earn some extra income.

She has already received three loans from Mahashakti. This is her fourth loan. With the present loan, she wants to invest in purchasing more leaf plates to increase the turnover of her business. Laxmi has an ambition to install a leaf-plate-making machine in the future and to educate her son for a bright career.

The four other members of the group, Dalimba, Tulasha, Ambika and Susama, are doing the same business: making leaf plates and selling them at a higher price.

loans.use: to purchase leaf plates to sell

loans.name: Adjoavie

texts.fr: Femme de 48ans, Adjoavie est restauratrice de profession. Elle revend du fufu à ses clients et sollicite un premier crédit pour acheter des ignames et autres ingrédients. Son souhait est d'aménager son restaurant et améliorer les conditions de vie de la famille. Elle est mariée à un huissier et mère de famille.
texts.en: A 48-year-old woman, Adjoavie is a restauranteur by trade. She sells 'fufu' (pounded yams or cassava served with a sauce) to her customers. She is requesting an initial loan to purchase some yams and other ingredients. Her wish is to fix up her restaurant and improve her family's living conditions. She is married to a bailiff and a mother with a family.

loans.use: to purchase yams and other ingredients for her catering.

loans.name: Maria Asunta

texts.es: Maria Asunta nació en la ciudad de Cusco pero vive en Paucartambo, ella tiene 36 años de edad y tiene una relación de unión libre de la cual tiene cuatro hijos, ella es una persona  trabajadora y emprendedora que saca adelante a su familia con el esfuerzo de su trabajo entonces su actividad económica principal es la venta de jugos, ella tiene un puesto de venta en uno de los mercados de la ciudad de Paucartambo, ella es una persona responsable por ese motivo le invitaron a participar en el banco comunal “Llapallanchis Llankasunchis” y en esta oportunidad  requiere el préstamo para comprar más insumos como por ejemplo frutas y azúcar, ella agradece y valora el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas mensuales con mucha responsabilidad.
texts.en:
Maria Asunta was born in the city of Cusco, but she lives in Paucartambo. She is 36, lives in a free union, and has four children. She is hardworking and enterprising in her efforts to support her family. Her main business is selling juices, and she has a stand in one of the Paucartambo markets. 

Because she is very responsible, she was asked to join the communal bank “Llapallanchis Llankasunchis.” She needs a loan to buy more merchandise such as fruits and sugar. She is thankful for and appreciates the loan and promises to make her monthly payments responsibly.

loans.use: to buy more merchandise such as fruits and sugar.

loans.name: Sabina

texts.es: Sabina nació en la ciudad de Paucartambo y vive junto con su familia, ella tiene 54 años de edad y tiene una relación de unión libre de la cual tiene cinco hijos, ella es una persona  trabajadora y emprendedora que saca adelante a su familia con el esfuerzo de su trabajo entonces su actividad económica principal es la venta de comida, ella tiene un restaurante en uno de los mercados de la ciudad de Paucartambo, ella es una persona responsable por ese motivo le invitaron a participar en el banco comunal “Llapallanchis Llankasunchis” y en esta oportunidad  requiere el préstamo para comprar más insumos como por ejemplo verduras, carnes, arroz y azúcar, ella agradece y valora el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas mensuales con mucha responsabilidad.
texts.en:
Sabina was born in Paucartambo and lives with her family. She is 54 and has five children with her free-union partner. She is hardworking and enterprising in her efforts to support her family. Her main business is selling prepared foods, and she has a restaurant in one of the Paucartambo markets.

Because she is responsible, she was asked to join the communal bank “Llapallanchis Llankasunchis.” She needs a loan to buy more supplies such as vegetables, meats, rice, and sugar. She is thankful and appreciative of the loan. She promises to make her monthly payments responsibly.

loans.use: to buy more supplies such as vegetables, meats, rice, and sugar.

loans.name: Collence

texts.en:
Collence is 36 years old and lives in the farming region of Chibombo District, Zambia. As a farmer, Collence has been working hard to put 8 children through school. Collence is requesting a Kiva loan so that he may purchase a water pump to irrigate his fields.

Collence has been selling large quantities of green peppers, tomatoes, and onions to markets in the capital city of Lusaka, and even to buyers from neighboring countries.  For the past 15 years, Collence has slowly been expanding his farm, but he has relied on family to help him in the labor-intensive task of watering using buckets. With a pump, Collence and his family will be able to irrigate their crops far more efficiently.

Water pumps can be a major boost for farmers such as Collence, who struggle to irrigate their crops with buckets during the dry season. A water pump allows for farmers to water their crops more regularly, while also increasing the area they are able to cultivate. Unfortunately, the upfront costs of such a water pump can be very prohibitive. Once he secures a loan, Collence will be able to get a water pump from Rent-to-Own, which will deliver the equipment to his farm, as well as provide training on how to use and maintain it.
 
Collence hopes to use new profits from an expanded farm to continue work on a new house for his family.  It is for this reason that he is asking Kiva lenders to assist him with a loan so that he can secure a water pump as soon as possible.

loans.use: to obtain a water pump for irrigation

loans.name: Terry

texts.en:
Terry, 51, is an experienced farmer and shop owner, with a family of twelve from the farming area of Chibombo District, Zambia. She is asking for a Kiva loan to buy a maize milling machine so that she can provide a milling service to over 300 families in her community. 

The maize milling machine takes raw maize (corn) and creates a maize flour which is the staple food in Zambia. Most families in Chibombo District grow maize on their small farms and store it and use it as their primary supply of food for the year. After the kernels are removed from the cob, they then have to be milled to create a flour, which can then be boiled to make what is locally called Nshima. Terry is already operating a small shop in the community and wants to expand by adding the maize mill as a service. 

Rent-to-Own has done market research in her community and has determined that the location for this equipment is ideal. The closest maize mill is 11km away from Terry, but it is currently not functional. This means most clients have to travel more than 15km to a roadside community, and since most clients walk or use their bicycles to travel to the maize mill, it is certain they will prefer to use this maize mill rather than traveling a longer distance. 

Equipment such as a maize mill can be a major boost for many business women such as Terry, as it allows for her to diversify her business. Unfortunately, the upfront costs of such a maize mill can be very prohibitive. Once she secures a loan, Terry will be able to get a maize mill from Rent-to-Own, which will deliver the equipment to her farm, as well as provide training on how to use and maintain it. With a maize mill, Terry can continue to build her business and better serve her community. 

This loan will help Terry on the long road to building up her viable businesses that can provide for her and her family throughout the year. It is for this reason Terry is asking Kiva lenders to help her with the loan so that she can secure a maize mill as soon as possible.

loans.use: to pay for a maize milling machine

loans.name: Jumbo

texts.en:
Jumbo, 24, recently completed secondary school and has been irrigating his small farm using buckets for the past three years.  He is requesting a Kiva loan so that he can buy a water pump to help him irrigate his crops.

Though he is young, he has experience growing many different crops including tomatoes, onions, fresh maize, sweet potatoes, and a local eggplant called ‘impwa.’ He has gained a lot of farming knowledge through attending training workshops put on by the government and by local NGOs, and he hopes that with a water pump he can see his business expand to new levels. 

Water pumps can be a major boost for farmers such as Jumbo, who struggle to irrigate their crops during the dry season. A water pump allows for farmers to water their crops more regularly, while also increasing the area they are able to cultivate. Unfortunately, the upfront costs of such a water pump can be very prohibitive. Once he secures a loan, Jumbo will be able to get a water pump from Rent-to-Own, which will deliver the equipment to his farm, as well as provide training on how to use and maintain it.

Jumbo hopes to be able to one day send his young children to school. He plans to significantly increase his crop production once he has secured a water pump and plans to use the new profits to support his family. It is for this reason he is asking Kiva lenders to assist him with a loan so that he can obtain a water pump as soon as possible.

loans.use: to obtain a water pump for irrigation

loans.name: Katani

texts.en:
Katani, 46, has seven children and is a farmer from Chibombo District, Zambia. He is asking for a Kiva loan so that he can buy a water pump to irrigate his vegetable crops. 

Using buckets, Katani has been able to draw water by hand from a nearby well and irrigate his green peppers and a local eggplant called “impwa.” For the past six years he has been able to sell his produce at several local markets and in the capital city, Lusaka. Without a water pump, however, it is difficult for him to further expand his farm.

Water pumps can be a major boost for farmers such as Katani. A water pump allows for farmers to water their crops more regularly, while also increasing the area they are able to cultivate. Unfortunately, the upfront costs of such a water pump can be very prohibitive. Once he secures a loan, Katani will be able to get a water pump from Rent-to-Own, which will deliver the equipment to his farm, as well as provide training on how to use and maintain it.

With a water pump, Katani hopes to significantly increase the area of his fields, and in turn, increase his profits. He hopes to use the profits to pay for school fees as all seven of his children are of school age. It is for this reason Katani is asking Kiva lenders to help him with a loan so that he can secure a water pump as soon as possible.

loans.use: to obtain a water pump for irrigation

loans.name: Kuña Joaju Group

texts.es:
El grupo llamado kuña joaju está en el ciclo uno, trabajando juntas y tratando de fomentar el trabajo en equipo. Ellas son de una zona bastante alejada y rural llamada Villa Ygatimi, una zona muy humilde y con poco acceso a ciertos servicios básicos, por lo que la fundación paraguaya apuesta en ellas dándoles esta oportunidad.
Una de las integrantes es la Sra. Isabelina, quien tiene plantaciones en su campo, también quiere poder empezar en la vena de comestibles, es por eso que solicita de este crédito para poder invertirlo en su campo para poder producir hortalizas para su hogar como también para su venta. Es una mujer muy trabajadora y emprendedora.
texts.en:
The communal bank Kuña Joaju is in its first loan cycle, and the members are working together and promoting teamwork. The members live in an outlying, rural area called Villa Ygatimi, a modest zone with little access to basic services. This is why Fundación Paraguaya is supporting the women with this opportunity.

Isabelina, one of the members, owns cropland and also wants to plant other crops. She has applied for a loan to invest in her land so that she can grow vegetables for her family's use and to sell. She is hardworking and enterprising.

loans.use: to invest in her vegetables fields.

loans.name: Fouzia

texts.en: Fouzia is a borrower with BRAC Pakistan. She lives in Lahore, Pakistan. She has two daughters and one son. Her husband sells vegetables from a hand cart. He delivers vegetables on streets and markets to generate income. He purchases a variety of fresh vegetables and sells them at good prices. He works very hard to fulfill his family's basic needs. It is very tough to deliver vegetables in the summer season, sometimes he feel very low because of the hot weather, but he still continues to work with full honesty and sincerity. Currently, he does not have enough savings to purchase vegetables from the field. That is why his wife, Fouzia, has requested a Kiva loan from its field partner BRAC Pakistan to purchase a variety of vegetables from the field. He will purchase fresh potatoes, tomatoes, lady fingers, cabbage, onions and lemons. The loan would be very helpful to continue his business. Fouzia wants to thank Kiva field partners and all the staff of BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: to purchase fresh potatoes, tomatoes, lady fingers, cabbage, onions and lemons to sell

loans.name: Yuliana

texts.es: Yuliana, a sus 21 años de edad se dedica a vender mercancía y productos por catálogo de una marca muy reconocida a nivel mundial; su idea de negocio surgió de la necesidad de obtener ingresos para aportar a la economía de su hogar y debido a la dificultad de conseguir oportunidades de empleo. Su experiencia en el área comercial, la obtuvo cuando laboró en un almacén aproximadamente 3 meses durante una temporada navideña. La cliente es una joven emprendedora, activa, pujante y dedicada a su labor, pues durante los 30 meses que lleva realizándola, le ha dado buenos resultados, incluso pudo pagar sus estudios de Técnica en Farmacéutica. Actualmente solicita el crédito con la intención de invertirlo en la compra de mercancía al por mayor (cremas corporales, cosméticos, perfumería, accesorios, entre otros) para aprovechar los descuentos que obtiene y los paquetes promocionales, con lo cual se reducen los costos de los artículos, para luego venderlos a precio de catálogo, aumentando su margen de ganancia. Es así como Yuliana desea salir adelante y seguir progresando, desea conseguir un buen empleo para ejercer su profesión y alternarlo con su negocio actual; así aumentará sus ingresos para ofrecer una mejor calidad de vida a sus padres y a su hermano, con quienes convive.
texts.en:
At 21 years old, Yuliana makes her living selling the merchandise and products by catalog of an internationally renowned brand. Her business idea was born from the need to have an income to add to her household's finances and due to the difficulty in obtaining job opportunities. She gained her experience in sales when she worked in a department store for approximately three months during the Christmas period.

Yuliana is a young enterprising woman, she is active, strong and dedicated to her work, given that during the 30 months that she has been performing it, she has got a good return; she was even able to pay for her pharmaceutical studies. 

She is currently seeking the loan to invest in the purchase of products in bulk (body cream, cosmetics, perfume, accessories and so on) to make the most of the discounts that she can get with promotional packets (meaning that the cost of the items is reduced), to then sell them at the catalog price therein increase her profit margin. This is how Yuliana hopes to get ahead in life and continue advancing, she wants to have a good job to exercise her profession and alternate it with her current business, in this way she will increase her income to offer her parents and her brother a better quality of life with whom she lives.

loans.use: to buy merchandise in bulk (body creams, cosmetics, perfume, accessories and more).

loans.name: Virgen De Fatima Group

texts.es:
El grupo Virgen de Fátima está en su primer ciclo  del programa de comité de mujeres, ellas son de la Ciudad de Curuguaty, una ciudad alejada de la capital, con poco acceso a ciertos medios de comunicación, de muy difícil acceso, y hasta se podría decir un poco insegura.
Una de las integrantes es la Sra. María, quien lucha por dar un bienestar a su familia por medio de su trabajo, que consiste en la cría y venta de animales de corral. Es un trabajo humilde, pero es su sustento y está tratando de ir mejorando. Hoy solicita de este crédito para poder invertirlo en la compra de balanceados para sus animales y así seguir con su trabajo como lo viene haciendo.
texts.en: The communal bank Virgen de Fátima is in its first loan cycle with the women's program. The members live in Curuguaty, a hard-to-reach and somewhat dangerous community on the outskirts of the capital with little access to the media. María, one of the members, strives to support her family through her work, which is raising and selling farmyard animals. The business is modest, but it is her livelihood, and she is trying to make it grow. She has applied for a loan to buy nutritious animal feed to continue with her business.

loans.use: to buy nutritious animal feed.

loans.name: Julia Pilar

texts.es: Julia tiene 51 años de edad y vive con su esposo, quien sufre de una enfermedad terminal. Debido a que la carga económica recae directamente sobre ella, decidió iniciar su propio negocio para generar ingresos suficientes que le permitieran solventar las necesidades básicas del hogar y los medicamentos de su esposo, pues él está incapacitado para trabajar. Montó una cafetería desde hace 6 años, donde ofrece mecato, gaseosas, alimentos fritos, confitería, entre otros, trabaja de Lunes a Domingo desde las 6:00 am hasta las 9:00 pm, con el fin de aprovechar al máximo el tiempo y atender toda la clientela. Julia es una mujer pujante, trabajadora, humilde y noble, lucha incansablemente velando por el bienestar de sus esposo, quien requiere de su apoyo. Actualmente solicita el crédito con el fin de invertirlo en la compra de surtido al por mayor (mecato, gaseosas, galletería, confitería, café, entre otros) y realizar unas adecuaciones locativas, esto le permitirá darle una mejor imagen a su negocio, cambiando la percepción de las personas que transitan por el lugar, con lo que podrá atraer nuevos clientes, para ofrecerles gran variedad de productos que satisfagan los gustos y necesidades de su clientela. De esta manera, Julia desea incrementar sus ingresos para seguir solventando las necesidades del hogar y para avanzar hacia el cumplimiento de su principal sueño que es tener su negocio ubicado en un local propio, que le genere suficientes ganancias para tener una solvencia económica favorable y ofrecer a su esposo una mejor calidad de vida.
texts.en:
Julia is 51 years old and lives with her husband who suffers from a terminal illness. Given that the financial burden falls directly on her, she decided to start her own business to generate sufficient income to enable her to cover the basic household costs and her husband's medication as he is unable to work. She set up a cafe six years ago where she sells cakes, fizzy drinks, fried food, sweets and so on. She works from Monday to Sunday from 6:00 am to 9:00 pm with the aim of making the most of time and attend to her customers. 

Julia is a strong woman, hardworking, humble and noble. She fights tirelessly, caring for the well-being of her husband who needs her support. She is currently seeking the loan to invest in the purchase of products in bulk (cakes, fizzy drinks, biscuits, sweets, coffee and so on) and to make a few small changes. This will allow her to give her business a better image, changing the perception of the people who go past the area with which she can attract new customers to offer them a greater variety of products which satisfy her customers' likes and needs. In this way, Julia wants to increase her income to continue covering the household needs and get closer to realizing her main dream which is of having her business on her own premises which will generate enough profits to have a strong financial solvency and offer her husband a better quality of life.

loans.use: to buy stock in bulk (cakes, fizzy drinks, biscuits, sweets, coffee and so on) and to make a few small changes .

loans.name: San Rafael Group

texts.es:
El comité San Rafael, son de la ciudad de Lambaré, el grupo pasa al 2do ciclo del programa de comité de mujeres. Todas ellas son mujeres que con gran esfuerzo están saliendo adelante.
Johana es vendedora de prendas de segunda mano, y comenta que le está yendo muy bien en sus ventas, ya que las prendas usadas están siendo más pedidas porque son más baratas. Es una persona con grandes ganas de salir adelante y es por eso que está luchando. Solicita de este crédito para poder comprar prendas de segunda mano y de esa forma seguir vendiendo sus prendas.
texts.en:
The members of the San Rafael committee are from the city of Lambaré. The group is in its second cycle of the women's committee program. All of its members are women who are getting ahead with great effort.

Johana sells second-hand clothing, and she says that she is doing very well with her sales as used clothing is more sought after because it is cheaper. She is someone with a great desire to get ahead and it is for this that she is striving. She is asking for this loan to be able to buy second-hand clothing and thus keep selling her clothing.

loans.use: to buy second-hand clothing to sell

loans.name: Saleem Taj

texts.en:
Saleem is a borrower of BRAC Pakistan. She lives in Lahore, Pakistan. She has three daughters and four sons.

Her husband manufactures saws.  Currently, he does not have enough savings to purchase iron blades and wooden handles for manufacturing saws. This business is the only source of income for his family. Therefore, it is necessary to continue this work. Otherwise, they will have to face major financial issues. That is why Saleem has requested this Kiva loan from the field partner, BRAC Pakistan. She will use it to purchase raw materials for her husband's saw manufacturing business. The loan amount would be very helpful, to enable him to continue his business. Saleem wants to thank Kiva and all staff of BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: to purchase iron blades and wooden handles, for manufacturing saws.

loans.name: Arance

texts.en:
Arance is a 38-year-old lady and married to Yusuf, a 41-year-old man. They’ve been blessed with two children, namely, Indah, 18, in the second year of Senior High School, and Angel, 14, in the second year of Junior High School.
 
Arance runs a kiosk business, to assist her husband by generating more income for her family. She initiated the business using her own capital. Bath soap, detergent, stationery, cigarettes, candies and snacks are available at her kiosk. 

Arance has just recently established a brand new kiosk, in a different area, alongside a highway. She needs to add more goods to the new kiosk, such as sugar, coffee, cooking oil, and kitchen equipment. Arance needs more money, in order to do so. Therefore, she requested a loan of IDR 10,000,000 from TLM. She really hopes that her business will run well, so she will be able to repay the loan to TLM.

loans.use: to buy goods for her new, second kiosk, including sugar, coffee, cooking oil, and kitchen equipment.

loans.name: Marciana

texts.en: Marciana lives in Gango, Ozamiz City, with her two children. She provides nipa roof-making services to make a living. Aside from doing this, she was engaged with a motorcycle transportation business providing transportation and rental. Marciana successfully repaid her previous loan from Gata Daku MPC, which she used to buy raw materials for nipa roof-making. Recently, she borrowed another loan to repair the motorcycle and buy spare parts.  In the future, she wants to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to repair her motorcycle and buy spare parts

loans.name: Gloria Esperanza

texts.es:
Gloria, vive con sus hijos, los cuales tienen edades de 8, 10 y 15 años, todos dependen ella, es por eso que se dedica a la elaboración y venta de pupusas para obtener ingresos, dicha actividad la realiza todos los días de 4:00pm a 8:00pm  y lo desempeña desde hace 10 años.
El préstamo que solicita le permitirá comprar la materia prima, tales como: maíz, frijoles, quesillo, chicharrón, condimentos, entre otros. Esta inversión le ayudara al fortalecimiento del negocio y adquirir ganancias.
Su sueño es tener más fuerte el negocio y que sus hijos sigan estudiando hasta culminar el bachillerato.
texts.en:
Gloria lives with her children, who are 8, 10 and 15 years old and all depend on her. For this reason she works making and selling pupusas (stuffed tortillas) to earn an income. She's been doing this for 10 years, working every day from 4:00 PM to 8:00 PM.

The loan she is requesting will allow her to purchase raw materials such as maize, beans, cheese, pork rind, condiments and other items. This investment will help her strengthen her business and make a profit.

Her dream is to have a stronger business and to have her children continue to study until they complete high school.

loans.use: to purchase maize, beans, cheese, pork rind, condiments and other items.

loans.name: Noshaba's Group

texts.en:
Noshaba is a borrower of BRAC Pakistan and the group leader of this three-person group. She lives in Lahore, Pakistan. She has four daughters and five sons. Her husband owns a toy shop, and that is how he fulfills the family's needs. He purchases a variety of toys, and sells them in the main market at a profitable price. Children love the variety he offers. 

Currently, the stock of his shop is almost finished. He does not have enough savings to purchase more toys. This business is the only source of income for his family. Therefore, it is necessary to continue this work. They are already going through financial isssues. If he were not able to continue his work, then his family would have to face more serious financial problems.

For this reason, Noshaba has requested a Kiva loan from the field partner, BRAC Pakistan. She will use the loan to help her husband to purchase a variety of toys to sell. The loan amount would be very helpful to the continuation of his business. Noshaba wants to thanks Kiva, field partners, and all staff of BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of toys for her husband to sell at the market

loans.name: Glenda Lizeth

texts.es: Glenda Lizeth de veintiséis años de edad vive junto a su compañero de vida Federico de 32 años y sus tres hijos menores de edad; ella es empleada de una empresa realizando bordados, además para complementar gastos vende diferentes tipos de fruta manzanas, naranja, guineos entre otros su esposo le ayuda con la venta, se han hecho de clientela pues las personas la prefieren porque vende buenas frutas además tiene precios accesibles, y el servicio es inigualable; Glenda es una mujer entregada a su labor, muy dispuesta siempre a aprovechar su tiempo y las oportunidades que se le presenten, el bienestar de su familia es su prioridad por eso trabaja duro para darles lo mejor, esta preocupada  porque ya es época de invierno y en su vivienda necesita levantar un muro de contención para evitar el ingreso de agua lluvia, el problema es que no posee de capital que la respalde pues sus ingresos no son los suficientes como para costear el gasto, por eso se ha decidido solicitarle a FUSAI un crédito que le permita comprar cemento, ladrillos, arena, herramientas etc. Glenda Lizeth es conocida en el lugar por su buena paga, esta muy contenta con la ayuda y se hace responsable de cancelar la deuda, además tiene la esperanza que podrá ofrecerle a su familia una mejor calidad de vida.
texts.en: Glenda Lizeth  is 26 years old and lives with her life partner, 32 year old Federico, and their three young children.  She works for a company doing embroidery and also sells different kinds of fruits, such as apples, oranges, bananas, and other things.  Her husband helps with the sales and they have a good customer base.  People prefer her because she sells good fruit at good prices and the service is unequalled.  Glenda is dedicated to her work and always ready to take advantage of her time and opportunities.  Her family’s wellbeing is her priority, so she works hard to give them the best.  She is worried because it’s already winter and her house needs a retaining wall to keep the water out when it rains.  The problem is that she doesn’t have the money because her earnings are too low.  She is asking for a loan through FUSAI so that she can buy cement, bricks, sand, tools, etc.  Glenda Liezth is known for repaying her debts and is very grateful for this assistance.  She will be responsible in repaying this loan and be able to provide a better quality of life for her family.

loans.use: to buy building materials.

loans.name: Alfredo Neftali

texts.es: Alfredo Neftalí de veintidós años de edad vive junto a su madre de cuarenta años, su hermano, su tía y su prima; Él es docente, labora como profesor de computación en una institución de educación, es un trabajo fijo que le permite aportar al hogar; Alfredo es un hombre dedicado a su labor y a toda su familia son las dos cosas mas importantes en su vida, se esfuerza todos los días por salir adelante y tener un futuro mejor, siempre esta pendiente de lo que se necesita, son de escasos recursos viven en una zona rural, su vivienda carece de agua potable, Alfredo al ver la necesidad de acceso al agua quiere instalarla en el hogar, además para mayor comodidad de los que la habitan desea levantar paredes en el baño y colocar una regadera, pero no cuenta con el suficiente capital pues sus ingresos no logran cubrir en su totalidad los gastos que esto requiere, por eso se decidió a solicitarle a FUSAI un crédito que le permita comprar tuberías, ladrillo, regadera, cemento etc. Alfredo Neftalí tiene buenas referencias de pago y es muy responsable, asegura que podrá saldar la deuda en el periodo establecido y a la vez tiene la confianza que le ofrecerá a su familia una vida plena como se la merecen.
texts.en:
Alfredo Neftalí is 22 years old and lives with his 52 year old mother, his brother, his aunt, and his cousin.  He is a teacher and teaches computing at a learning institute.  It’s steady work that allows him to support his household.  Alfredo is dedicated to his work and to his family.  These are the two most important things in his life and he works hard every day to get ahead and have a better future.  He is always on the lookout for what he needs, is of limited resources and lives in a rural zone.

His home lacks potable running water and Alfredo wants to run it into his house.  He also wants to add walls to the bathroom and add a shower, but he doesn’t have enough money to pay the cost in full, so he is asking for a loan through FUSAI, that will allow him to buy pipes, bricks, a shower, cement, etc.  Alfredo Neftalí comes with good credit references and is very responsible.  He promises that he will repay his loan on time and is sure that he will be able to provide his family with the good quality of life they deserve.

loans.use: to buy building materials.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.es:
La señora  Elizabeth tiene 27 años de edad está casada hace 3 años con el señor Jorge de 30 años, el matrimonio tienen un hijo de dos años quien es el motivo de lucha de la pareja.
La señora  Elizabeth se dedica a la venta de perfumes y joyas desde hace 8 años mucho antes de casarse, su padre le facilito el capital inicial y ahora trabaja ayudada por su esposo y juntos llevan sin problema este negocio y cada día van aumentando su clientela y por ende su ingreso.
Solicita el préstamo para la compra de perfumes y joyas que le permitirá ofrecer variedad y así poder cubrir todos los pedidos de  su clientelas.
texts.en:
Elizabeth is 27 years old, married to 30 year old Jorge, and has a two year old son who is the couple’s main motivation.  Elizabeth has been selling perfumes and jewelry for the past eight years, long before she was married.  She works with help from her husband and together they run this business and increase their customer and income daily.

She is asking for this loan to buy perfumes and jewelry that will allow her to offer a greater variety to her customers, and in this way cover their requests.

loans.use: to buy perfumes and jewelry.

loans.name: Lanie Jean

texts.en:
Lanie Jean lives in Macupa, Tangub City, with her family. She is 20 years old, married and has one child. 

To make a living, she plants, harvests, and sells bananas while her husband operates a motorcycle transportation business.

In 2009, Lanie Jean joined Gata Daku Multi-purpose Cooperative (GDMPC) to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lanie Jean successfully repaid her previous loan, which she used for her farm. She plans to cultivate all the vacant land for more harvest in the future. Without hesitation, she borrowed a loan of 8,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) to cover the costs of land preparation and fertilization. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to cover the costs of land preparation and fertilization.

loans.name: Reymunda

texts.en:
Reymunda is married and has four children. She lives in Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She owns and operates a farm, cultivating bananas in the local community to earn a living. She also is engaged in a retail business.

In 2007, she joined Gata Daku MPC. She successfully repaid her previous loan, which she used to improve her farm. Now she has requested another loan, this time in the amount of 15,000 PHP. She will use it to purchase goods to sell at her store, including canned goods, sugar, rice and livestock feed. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business, to improve and expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase goods to sell at her store, including canned goods, sugar, rice and livestock feed

loans.name: Keo

texts.en:
Keo is the sole breadwinner in a family comprised of herself and three kids. One child is in school, and the other two are too small for school. Keo is 38 years old and a local farmer. She cultivates rice, as the main source of her income. She has been involved in this current business for six years.

This is the second loan for Keo with VisionFund (Kiva’s partner). The successful previous loan, which she has fully repaid, enabled her to support her living better than before. Now, she is in need of working capital to support her cash crop. Therefore, she takes a new loan of 2,000,000 KHR, in order to buy fertilizer and pesticide for her farmland. She hopes that she can expand her business and make a good profit.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and pesticide for her rice farm

loans.name: Isatu

texts.en:
Meet 28-year-old Isatu from Tombo, Western rural area in Sierra Leone. She is married with two children, ages 3 years and 7 years. One of her children is currently attending school. 

In 2009, Isatu established her retail business.  She started the business to improve her standard of living. She works at the business 7 days per week and 15 hours per day. She says that the main challenge to her business is the transportation problem and poor road network within her operation area.

Isatu requires a loan in order to buy more brooms and charcoal for resale. She hopes that the extra income from this loan will allow her to take good care of her family and increase her business. 

In the future, Isatu plans to expand her business more.  She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy more brooms and charcoal for resale.

loans.name: Maa Mangala Self Help Group

texts.en:
Maa Mangala Self Help Group was formed with nine members in 2008 in a small village in Odisha. They all came together to help each other and solve the social issues among them, save money and provide financial support to their families. They chose Mamata as the leader of their group. The lady sitting second from the left-hand side of the photograph is Mamata. She is a 32-year-old woman living with her husband and her two children. 

For ten years, Mamata’s husband has been working as a farmer to support his small family. It is not sufficient to manage the family's financial needs, however. So Mamata is helping her husband by working with him and being involved in the milk business. She has five years experience in this business. She has requested a loan to buy a cow and fodder so that she can add to her family’s income. 

Mamata says that by selling milk, she can support her family and she can send her children to a good school; through that, she can provide better education to her children.

loans.use: to pay for purchasing a cow and fodder for her business.

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
This is 37-year-old Janet. She lives in Margibi County, which has the largest producing rubber plantation in Liberia. She and her fiancée live together along with their four children, ages ranging from 1 to 18, three of whom are in school. Her fiancée works with Firestone security. 

Janet did not attend school, but she has been good at managing her business for over ten years. She described herself as a hardworking woman. She received little money from her fiancée to establish her business. She enjoys her business because she makes more profit and has more customers. She sells for ten hours a day, six days a week.

She is requesting a loan to buy more rubber dishes, such as tubs, buckets, bowls, cups, etc. for her business. 

She plans to build a house. She likes to say thanks to the supporters of BRAC Liberia.

loans.use: to buy more rubber dishes, such as tubs, buckets, bowls, cups, etc. for her business.

loans.name: Koso            B

texts.en:
Meet 50-year-old Koso, from Waterloo Eastern area in Freetown. She is married and has two children, ages 9 and 26 years.  She began her business because she wanted to create her own source of income, instead of depending on her husband. In 2009, Koso established her general store business.  She works at the business from 8:00 AM to 12:00 PM, Monday to Friday. She says that the main challenges to her business are price inflation and transportation difficulties.

Koso requires a loan in order to purchase more items to sell, like cigarettes, biscuits, soft drinks and pure water. She hopes that the extra income from this loan will allow her to pay her child's school fees and to buy a piece of land. In the future, Koso plans to own the biggest shop in the community. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to purchase more items to sell, like cigarettes, biscuits, soft drinks, and pure water.

loans.name: Neheru Group

texts.en:
Iswariama is a housewife aged 38 years, who lives with her husband and four children in a rural village named Basuguda in Rayagada district of Odisha state in India. The lady standing second from the left raising her hand is Iswariama. 

She has been running a grocery shop for the last  four years and also has worked as the main cook for marriage parties in nearby villages. Her family gets a monthly income of 6,500 INR which is very little to cover her family's expenses. Presently, she, along with her family members, lives in a thatched house. 

She wants to access a loan from Mahashakti to purchase rice, oil, sugar, salt, tea, potatoes, onions, garlic, and washing powder, etc. for her grocery shop. This is the first loan of the group from Mahashakti.

The other three members of the group Santoshi, Rashmita and Mutalluama are doing bamboo work, a "leaf plate" business and a grocery shop respectively.

loans.use: to purchase rice, oil, sugar, salt, tea, potatoes, onions, garlic, and washing powder.

loans.name: Ann Adishakti Mahila Self Help Group

texts.en:
Pratima is a 42-year-old lady living with her husband and one child. She owns and manages a dairy farm where she has a few cows and buffaloes. She sells five litres of milk per day and earns 3,000 Indian rupees (INR) per month. Her monthly income is very small for a family of three persons. She wants to purchase two Jersey cows for her farm, as demand for cow's milk is high in her village. She also has a plan to repair the shed for her cattle and make it bigger. 

Pratima, along with her group members, has requested a loan of 165,000 INR. She will use her portion of the loan for purchasing two cows and renovating the shed. In the future, she wants to expand her farm and sell more milk products like yogurt, butter, etc. She has a dream to give a quality life to her family and save some money for her child's future. All the members of this group are engaged in the dairy business.

loans.use: to pay for purchasing two cows and renovating the cattle shed.

loans.name: Maame

texts.en:
Due to difficult circumstances, Maame did not have access to any form of formal education, yet this has not stopped her from achieving her dream of becoming an entrepreneur. 

Currently, Maame sells vegetables and food items in Brameng (near Cape Coast). She has been doing so for about two years. As a single mother with a number of children, Maame uses all her income to feed and provide for her family. 

Maame will use the loan to purchase an increased amount of vegetables and food items, which will aid her in improving her overall sales. Maame wants to use the future profits from her expanded business to ensure that all her children are able to receive an education.

loans.use: to purchase an increased amount of vegetables and food items, which will aid her in improving her overall sales.

loans.name: Korpo

texts.en:
Korpo is 36 years old. She lives and works in Buchanan, the capital city of Grand Bassa County, which is located by the sea. Most people in this city are Bassa speakers, one of the indigenous languages of Liberia. She is married to a driver. Korpo did not go to school and has three children between 1 and 11 years old. Two are in school, and they all live at home. 

For the past ten years, Korpo has been selling slippers and lappa (fabric). She started her business with money given to her by her husband, and she learned trading from her friends. She likes how the customers buy when she sells. She spends ten hours on her business from Monday to Saturday. 

She is requesting a loan to purchase more slippers and lappa for her business. She hopes to build her own house.

loans.use: to purchase more slippers and lappa (fabric) for her business.

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Lucy is a Liberian.  She is residing in Buchanan, the capital city of Grand Bassa County.  The county is located by the sea and is known for their beaches and fish.  In addition, many logging companies are located in the county.  People in Buchanan are known in the country for their love of 'fufu,' a cassava-based dough typically eaten with soup or sauce.

Lucy is 45, married, and has two children, aged 19 and 25.  Only one is currently living at home and attending school. Lucy has a shop, where she sells cold water, rice, drinks, and other goods. She has had the shop for the past 13 years.  On average, she works ten hours per day at her business, from Monday to Saturday.  She started her business with a little bit of capital from her husband. She transports her merchandise by taxi.  She cites too few goods in her shop, as her biggest challenge.  She enjoys the profit-making of the business.
